<caption>Course Outline</caption>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">School</td><td>School of Engineering</td>
<td class="rowhead1">College</td><td>College of Science and Engineering</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">Credit level (Normal year taken)</td><td>SCQF Level 8 (Year 2 Undergraduate)</td>
<td class="rowhead1">Availability</td><td>Available to all students</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">SCQF Credits</td><td>10</td>
<td class="rowhead1">ECTS Credits</td><td>5</td>
</tr>
<tr>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">Summary</td><td colspan="99">This is an introduction course to the techniques and equipment used in the generation, transmission, distribution and utilisation of electrical power.  It gives a basic understanding of how a power system operates and the problems facing electricity utilities. The design and main operating features of different types of motors and generators are also covered.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">Course description</td><td colspan="99">
    
    Introduction to Electrical Circuits<br/>
Introduction to Power Systems<br/>
Electrical Safety &amp; Wiring<br/>
Phasor Representation of AC Signals<br/>
AC Power<br/>
Complex Impedances<br/>
Real &amp; Reactive Power<br/>
Three Phase Systems<br/>
An introduction on electrical machines and transformers<br/>
DC Machines<br/>
Induction Machines<br/>
Synchronous Machines<br/>
<br/>
Laboratory:<br/>
One 3-hour laboratory, wiring and testing a motor control panel.<br/>
</td>
</tr>

<td class="rowhead1" stlye="width:15%;">Additional Information (Assessment)</td>
<td colspan="14">100% written examination.<br/>
Any student who does not attend and perform satisfactorily on the Power Engineering 2 laboratory is deemed to have failed the course, as it tests Competency regarding important safety aspects of power engineering.<br/>
<br/>
The School has a 40% Rule for 1st and 2nd year courses, i.e. you must achieve a minimum of 40% in coursework and 40% in written exam components, as well as an overall mark of 40% to pass a course. If you fail a course you will be required to re-sit it. You are only required to re-sit components which have been failed.</td>

<!-- Learning outcomes, FB 1/4/11 add other learning outcomes for ECA -->
<table class="sitstablegrid">
<caption>Learning Outcomes</caption>
<tr>
<td>
    On completion of this course, the student will be able to:
    <ol style="font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit;">
<li>Have a basic understanding of the operation of large electrical power systems, and their main constituent components.</li><li>Understand the operating principles of several different types of electrical machine.</li><li>Be able to perform basic calculations on electrical power systems and machines, while appreciating the limitations of such calculations.</li><li>Have an appreciation of safe practice in the design and construction of electrical power circuits.</li>
</ol>
</td>
</tr>
</table>

<caption>Reading List</caption>

edition, McGraw-Hill, ISBN: 9780071151559</td></tr>
